title: IOOF scuttles bonuses but Kelaher gets $2.6m golden handshake
text:
“This is to encourage long-term decision making in the interest of the group’s clients, shareholders and other stakeholders,” she said.

IOOF managing director Renato Mota – who was promoted from general manager of wealth to CEO on June 29 – took home $857,119, including $68,475 in long-term incentives. His total package including unvested share rights weighed in at a more substantial $1.23 million.

Under the terms of his contract, he is no longer eligible for a short-term bonus but his long-term incentives in the future are equal to 100 per cent of his $1.2 million fixed salary.

Kelaher, who resigned after a widely criticised appearance at the royal commission and the prudential regulator's decision to launch legal action, took home a salary of $1.3 million and a termination payment of $1.27 million after he quit in April.

Unvested shares

The remuneration committee also said it would “reserve” its decision on 72,052 unvested shares awarded to him in the 2017 and 2018 financial years, which are worth $546,882 at the current price.

Non-executive directors at IOOF have escaped any penalty but the board did elect to hold directors' fees steady for the next 12 months. Directors are paid from a pool of $1.25 million.

Chairman Allan Griffiths was upbeat about the prospects for the firm, saying the changes under way would put the company at the forefront of the sector.

“We believe that the work being undertaken will leave us with a governance model that is best practice within the industry. We have taken very positive steps to improve relationships with all stakeholders, particularly with our regulators,” Mr Griffiths said.

The annual report arrived on the same day the corporate regulator imposed additional licence conditions, requiring IOOF to appoint a majority of independent directors with “relevant” skills and experience, as the firm bedded down the acquisition of ANZ’s pensions and investments business.

ASIC commissioner Danielle Press said the regulator was “serious about improving the quality of governance and conflicts management” in the industry and would use its power to protect consumers from “the risk of poor conduct or vulnerabilities to conflicts of interest”.
description: The divisive wealth management company has cancelled top executives' short-term bonuses because of the poor share price performance.
